The beginning of this bridge employs a chord structure similar to the intro to “Bohemian Rhapsody”, one of Queen’s most popular songs: Gm7 C7 F7 Bb.
[Verse 2]
Before this verse, there’s an instrumental breakdown that starts with bicycle bells (pilfered from every cycling shop near the studio ) following into a trademark Brian May guitar solo.
Hot dog, I say, Cool it man

“Hot dog!” is an expression used to show delight or enthusiasm.

Freddie Mercury continues the trend of saying the opposite of whatever the other person is saying by saying to “cool it man”, meaning to calm down.

Hot and cold are opposites as well.
You say coke, I say ’caine

Don’t offer Freddie Mercury a Coca-Cola; He’d much prefer something stronger.



In fact, cocaine and a veritable cornucopia of other substances abounded in the early days of the Tour De France.
You say bark, I say bite
Alludes to the idiom, “his bark is worse than his bite,” referring to a person whose actions don’t live up to their threats. The speaker values doing over talking.
You say black, I say white
The speaker will defiantly contradict whatever constraining messages he feels society is trying to force on him.  As the song continues, he will provide a number of examples of this tendency.

You say God, Give me a choice!
 You say Lord, I say, Christ!
 I don’t believe in Peter Pan
 Frankenstein or Superman

The speaker wants the freedom to choose what to believe without having any religion shoved down his throat. When lectured about the Lord, he takes His name in vain, and mentions a few other fictional characters he doesn’t believe in.



Raised by Parsi parents in Zanzibar and India, Mercury grew up in the Zoroastran religion.  It’s unclear what, if any, beliefs he held as an adult.
Income tax, I say Jesus

The UK historically has had extraordinary high income tax rates for the very rich.  Queen recorded JAZZ outside of the UK in an attempt to escape these taxes.

Queen were not the first British rock stars to publicly complain about tax rates. The Beatles famously wrote about this in the song “Taxman”, where they griped about an effective tax rate of 95%. The Kinks also sang about high taxes in “Sunny Afternoon”.

Interestingly, Mercury would shortly receive a break from these high tax rates. Just one year after this song was released, newly-elected Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher lowered the top income tax rate in the UK from 83% to 60%. Maybe Maggie was a Queen fan.

 I want to ride my bicycle
 I want to ride it where I like

Freddie uses bicycling as a metaphor for being allowed to live his life without the interference of others. The key line here is ‘I want to ride it where I like.’ Freddie also uses the image of cycling to represent freedom from influence in “Crazy Little Thing Called Love”.



It’s important that Freddie chose the self-sustainable, independent cyclist for this metaphor.  In an  age where everyone is driving cars and relying on resources from others, Freddie is pedaling forward with his own two legs.
Cartier, I say please

Cartier is a famous jeweler established in Paris, France. Given the general tone of Freddie’s responses, this one is unlikely to be “Yes, please”, but rather “Oh, please” in the tone of voice that says “I’m insulted by the very suggestion”.
